results.title: Victoria's Favourite Things. Segment 5
results.brief_description: The results of July 2004’s Open House weekend program ‘Victoria’s Favourite Things’. This segment features Karen’s hat; Lyn from Port Melbourne has three ‘favourite’ children; David from Endeavour Hills’ favourite things include his family heritage and his novel; and Erica from Melbourne introduces us to Tigger.

results.title: Victoria's Favourite Things. Segment 4
results.brief_description: The results of July 2004’s Open House weekend program ‘Victoria’s Favourite Things’. This segment features Hamish from Hawthorn talking about his Game Boy; Mike from Montrose and his keyring; Melissa from East Malvern adores her Dogs; The Monroe Family show us ‘Fairy Ted’ and a geometry book; Atlanta from Abbotsford recalls an idyllic spot called ‘Warm Baths’; Nicholas from Doncaster East follows sports - a lot; Seth from both Istanbul and Ivanhoe talks about sailing; and Isobel from Hawthorn shows us her CareBears

results.title: Victoria's Favourite Things. Segment 3
results.brief_description: The results of July 2004’s Open House weekend program ‘Victoria’s Favourite Things’. This segment has David from Birregurra talking about his new Motorbike; Paul, Louise, Ella and Matthew show us a Duck and Mr Pumpkin Head; Lucy from Perth shares a Poem; Alisha and Anna from Canterbury talk about Teddy Sascha and Alisha; Mary from Watsonia explains her passion for her horse; Mark and Liz talk about their kids; and Danielle from Melbourne discusses her favourite film ‘Chopper’.

results.title: Victoria's Favourite Things. Segment 1
results.brief_description: The results of July 2004’s Open House weekend program ‘Victoria’s Favourite Things’. This segment features Norma from Swan Hill talking about a Mallee root; Alex from Melbourne discusses 19th century literature; Adam Elliott is still thrilled by his Oscar; Lewis loves the Spy Kids movies; Alfred of Reservoir tells us that retirement is his favourite thing and a visitor from Hong Kong bursts into song!

results.title: Get in the picture at ACMI - Open House 25-7-04
results.brief_description: The results of July 2004’s Open House weekend program ‘In the Picture’ - a free taste of our popular Screen Adventures Program. Members of the public were invited to walk on and act up in front of ACMI’s blue screen ‘film genre’ sets.

results.title: Deep Space: Sensation & Immersion [exhibition] : archival material
results.brief_description:
“Deep Space: Sensation & Immersion” was an ACMI Screen Gallery Exhibition, held 26 October 2002 - 27 January 2003.
See Exhibition activity record “Deep Space” (ID 3) for more information
The international and Australian contemporary artists in this exibition present environments, or chambers, for the visitor to participate in an all encompassing aesthetic experience. The audience is invited to move within the art works, to explore their physical construction, their digital presence, their filmic pulse and their saturated expanses of colour and light. The experiences vary: some are quiet, some intangible, others humourous or uncanny. Each involves an ephemeral medium, whether it be light, video or digital imagery and each encloses the viewer in a confined space only to offer them access to another expanded sense of space altogether. This exhibition offers visitors a memorable and transformative experience of being immersed in ‘deep space’, the kineasthetic, visual, aural and informational totality of the art works.

results.title: Hold: Vessel #1 and Vessel #2
results.material_description: video, projection, glass, colour and sound
results.brief_description:
Hold: Vessel 1 is a magical interactive experience in which visitors to the gallery try to catch a mesmerizing series of projected visions in a delicate glass bowl - echoing the wondrous views of the world made possible with the first microscopes, underwater cameras and astronomical cinematography.
Lynette Wallworth began her career in photography, and has also worked in short film, installation and performance. She creates installation spaces that require activation by the participant/viewer. To collect the images used in Hold: Vessel 1 she collaborated with scientific image libraries and specialist cinematographers, as part of her ongoing investigation into imaging technologies that enable us to see the world in ways otherwise inaccessible to the naked human eye. Hold: Vessel 1 consists of video projections with directional sound scape beamed from above into a darkened space. The visitor is invited to take hold of a glass bowl and catch the images within it, finding the point at which the vision is most clear and resolved. A personal portal opens to us as we cradle the bowl in our hands. Imagery in ‘Hold’ is derived mainly from Australian scientists and specialist cinematographers including: David Hannan, who has adapted medical imaging technology to film extreme macro images of the Great Barrier Reef, Anya Salih, who investigates coral fluorescence and Greg Rouse, Marine Biologist. The work is designed as a vessel to hold a changing pool of imagery. Hold: Vessel 1 will change in time as time changes the environments it reflects.

results.title: Festival of kites
results.brief_description: Sponsored by the City of Darebin, this short video documents the Festival of Kites, organized by the North Eastern Melbourne Chinese Association and by the Australian Kite Association. An all-day event held in parklands in Preston, this multicultural event includes performances by comedians, Indian dancers and a Chinese Choir.

results.title: BIT Plane
results.brief_description:
The Bitplane video captures an aero-portrait of a richly mythologised territory - the Silicon Valley in California, home to the largest concentration of wealth in California since the Gold Rush. The Bitplane’s mission takes it deep into the heart of the Valley, to view the source and progress of the Information Age. Due to its tiny dimensions, the Bitplane is able to enter territory inaccessible to other aircraft.

One of the issues the Bitplane engages with on this reconnaissance flight is the threat of the camera to information space. Cameras are not permitted into the corporate research parks in teh Valley, according to the logic that visitors could steal intellectual property by taking photographs. This reveals an assumption that information is something you can photograph, a thing - not the product of a community or expertise or a social network of shared discourse but something you could steal with a camera.

From the Artist Statement provided for PROOF exhibition, Dec 2004.
